data.title: DUSK (DUSK) - Aegis Protocol Upgrade - 03 March 2026
data.description:
The Aegis Protocol Upgrade is a mandatory network upgrade for all DUSK node operators, activating on 3 March 2026 at 11:00 AM UTC. According to the Dusk Foundation’s announcement, the release is described as the project’s most significant upgrade so far, focused on strengthening the network and hardening security while laying technical groundwork for future features. For traders, successful execution reduces protocol and security risk, which can support a higher valuation multiple if market confidence increases. However, any implementation issues, node fragmentation, or unforeseen bugs around activation could temporarily disrupt network reliability and weigh on DUSK price.

Dusk
@DuskFoundation

Aegis Protocol Upgrade is coming.

Our most significant upgrade to date that strengthens our network, hardens security and lays the foundation for what's next.

Activation: 3rd March at 11AM UTC

This is a mandatory upgrade for all node operators. pic.twitter.com/IBlfaPrVDS

Feb 27, 2026

data.title: THORWallet (TITN) - TITN Community Unlock - 03 March 2026
data.description:
The TITN Community Unlock on 3 March 2026 at 15:00 CET (14:00 UTC) lets users deploy previously unlocked TITN to increase their share of a 5,000,000 TITN airdrop. As outlined in THORWallet’s post, merged unlocks allow holders to consolidate and use unlocked tokens to boost rewards, with top wallets targeting 200,000+ TITN. Mechanically, this creates a short-term incentive to accumulate or retain TITN to maximize airdrop allocation, which can generate buy pressure and higher on-chain activity into the event. After distribution, increased circulating supply and concentrated large rewards may introduce sell pressure, so traders should watch vesting behavior and on-chain flows closely.

THORWallet - Onchain Finance
@Thorwallet

TITN Community Unlock

March 3rd · 15:00 CET ️

Merged TITN unlocks.

You can now use your unlocked TITN to actively increase your share of the 5,000,000 TITN airdrop.

Top wallets estimate 200,000+ TITN rewards.

Unlock → Participate → Compoundhttps://t.co/EsyLhCM8Tx

Feb 27, 2026

data.title: Illuvium (ILV) - Beyond New Wave - 12 March 2026
data.description:
Illuvium is launching a new wave of its Illuvium Beyond content on 12 March 2026. In the project’s teaser, the team confirms that a fresh “Illuvium Beyond” wave will drop on that date, signaling another cycle of collectible or ecosystem-related releases. For ILV, new content waves can drive user engagement, secondary-market activity, and speculative interest around the broader Illuvium ecosystem, which may translate into higher demand for ILV exposure if participants expect increased platform traction. However, the direct on-chain economic impact depends on how much this wave actually uses ILV or contributes to protocol revenue, so price reaction may be driven more by sentiment than fundamentals.

Kieran.eth
@KieranWarwick

Illuvium Beyond.

New wave dropping March 12. pic.twitter.com/Kq8RnEXdYv

Feb 27, 2026

data.title: Applied Optoelectronics Shares Surge On Narrower 4Q Loss, 1Q Revenue Outlook Beat
data.description:
By Amira McKee

Shares of Applied Optoelectronics soared after the semiconductor company narrowed its fourth-quarter loss on better-than-expected revenue, and projected first-quarter revenue that beat analyst estimates.

The stock was up 42% to $76.29 in midday Friday trading, after touching a new 52-week high of $79.50 earlier in the session. The shares have more than tripled in the past year and are on pace for the largest percent gain since November 2024.

The maker of optical networking products recorded a fourth-quarter net loss of $2 million, or three cents a share, compared with a loss of $119.7 million, or $2.60 a share, a year earlier.

Adjusted loss came in at one cent a share, outperforming the loss of 11 cents a share that Wall Street had anticipated, according to FactSet.

Revenue jumped 34% to $134.3 million, topping the $132.3 million that analysts polled by FactSet expected.

Applied Optoelectronics anticipates logging a first-quarter adjusted net loss of $7 million to $300,000, on revenue in the range of $150 million to $165 million. Wall Street forecast an adjusted loss of $3.8 million and revenue of $153 million, according to FactSet.

Write to Amira McKee at amira.mckee@wsj.com

data.title: How Tech Firms Are Enforcing AI Use — WSJ
data.description:
By Conor Grant

This is an edition of The Future of Everything newsletter, a look at how innovation and technology are transforming the way we live, work and play. If you're not subscribed, sign up here .

AI use is no longer optional if you work in tech.

While many sectors are still experimenting with artificial intelligence, the tech industry has moved to the next phase: tracking their workers' use of AI tools — and enforcing it if they have to.

This week, Katherine Bindley and Katherine Blunt report on tech companies that are factoring AI use into performance reviews and trying to track productivity gains.

From small startups to giants including Amazon, Alphabet's Google and Meta, tech companies are measuring it and in certain cases factoring it into performance reviews. For some jobs, candidates aren't even considered unless they can demonstrate AI fluency.

The approximate share of tech-industry workers who said their direct manager expects AI use in day-to-day work as of last October, up from 32% just eight months before, according to a survey from AI consulting firm Section

Even in an industry that tends to drive workplace trends, AI adoption hasn't been easy. Tech workers have many of the same feelings about AI as the broader population, including skepticism about how much time it's actually saving them. There's also the added anxiety of hearing their own CEOs talking about how AI will ultimately lead to smaller workforces.

More on this topic:

  • What AI executives tell their own kids about the jobs of the future. (Read)
  • The do's and don'ts of using AI to write performance reviews. (Read)
  • WSJ's Callum Borchers shares ways to stay sane in the AI skills race. (Read)

🤔 What are your thoughts on AI enforcement in the workplace? Send me your thoughts, questions and predictions at future@wsj.com (if you're reading this in your inbox, you can just hit reply).

More of What's Next: Apple's American Chip Push; Keeping Tabs on Grandma; a 'Fitbit for Farts'

Apple is pushing to build an all-American chip. Under pressure to diversify its supply chain away from Taiwan, the company is investing in domestic suppliers. To find out how far Apple still has to go, Rolfe Winkler went on an exclusive visit to several suppliers.

Personal Tech columnist Nicole Nguyen says Apple should copy Samsung's new security screen ASAP. She tested a new smartphone feature called Privacy Display, which obscures mobile screens from people nearby — and says this new tech could keep us safer.

You can monitor mom and dad without becoming Big Brother. Devices ranging from in-home sensors to location trackers can help families keep tabs on their aging loved ones while also respecting their privacy, writes Julie Jargon.

It's called the "Fitbit for farts," and it's no joke, writes Christopher Mims. Researchers have developed a tiny, battery-powered hydrogen sensor that continuously monitors a wearer's flatulence, with the aim of collecting data to improve digestive health.

Future Feedback

Last week, we reported on companies that are using converted jet engines to power data centers. Readers shared their thoughts on how these conversions will affect the power generation business:

  • "Airport noise next to landowners -- on top of the hum of the data centers and emergency diesel backup?! We have several data centers being built within five miles from our 'rural' houses -- some literally a few hundred feet away. We're not happy as is. The proposed pace of construction is not considering the real 'human' impact to neighbors. County commissioners are only looking at dollar signs, and not human impacts." -- Mark Slivka, Georgia
  • "This may be a godsend energy stopgap. Ultimately, more nuclear power is the long-term solution -- but it is a long-term solution." -- T.G. Nelson, Wisconsin
  • "This is a perfect example of how our capitalist economy operates. When supply and demand are out of balance, increasing prices and lack of supply bring new manufacturers and technologies into the market. 'The invisible hand' is alive and well." -- Joseph Messino, New York
  • "If you think residential neighbors are upset about having data centers built nearby in the latest version of Nimbyism, just wait to see the huge 'stink' (pun intended) they'll make about jet engine exhaust engulfing their neighborhoods!" -- Joseph Subits, Georgia

(Responses have been condensed and edited.)

Elsewhere in the Future

  • Women are falling in love with AI, and it's a problem for Beijing. (The New York Times)
  • America was winning the race to find Martian life. Then China jumped in. (MIT Technology Review)
  • Employers to job seekers: Your AI résumé isn't fooling anyone. (The Washington Post)

About Us

Thanks for reading The Future of Everything. We cover the innovation and tech transforming the way we live, work and play. This newsletter was written by Conor Grant. Get in touch with us at future@wsj.com. Got a tip for us? Here's how to submit.

See more from The Future of Everything at wsj.com/future-of-everything.

data.title: BMW launches fresh recall over potential cable issue
data.description:
German premium carmaker BMW has launched a fresh recall affecting hundreds of thousands of vehicles worldwide over a potential fire hazard, according to KBA, Germany's motor vehicle authority.

The authority said on its website that 337,374 vehicles of the i7, i5, 5, 7 and M5 series were potentially affected, with manufacture dates between 2022 and 2025.

It warned that an improper installation of the cockpit wiring harness could cause damage to cables when replacing the microfilter, resulting in a short circuit with smoke development and fire.

"No accidents are known to have occurred in connection with this fault pattern", a BMW spokesperson was quoted as saying by local news agency dpa.

data.title: Bund yields head for steepest monthly drop since April as flight to safety gathers pace
data.description:
Key points:
  • AI-driven investment reassessment cools risk appetite
  • German Bunds seen as transitory safe asset
  • Gap between French and German yields narrowest since June

By Niket Nishant

Germany's 10-year yield was set on Friday for its biggest monthly drop since last April's tariff turmoil, as government bonds globally benefit from investor anxiety over artificial intelligence and geopolitical tensions.

A burst of AI-driven investment has prompted investors to reassess both the durability of the spending spree and the scale of disruption that the technology could unleash on labour markets.

The reassessment has cooled risk appetite and triggered a flight to safe-haven assets such as government bonds.

Bond yields move inversely to prices.

The yield on 10-year Bunds, the euro zone benchmark, dipped 4.5 basis points to 2.649%, their lowest since November 13. It was on course to finish the month roughly 19 bps lower. (DE10YT=RR)

"Capital flows are shifting to Europe and European debt is emerging as a transitory safe asset," said Ludovic Subran, chief economist at Allianz Investment Management. "Global investors are increasingly using Europe, and particularly core markets like the German Bund, as a global safe asset substitute."

Investors are also tracking developments in the U.S.-Iran standoff. Talks on the longstanding nuclear dispute ended on Thursday without a breakthrough, though there were some signs of progress, according to mediating country Oman.

INFLATION DATA IN THE SPOTLIGHT

European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde said earlier this week that policymakers expect inflation to settle near their 2% target in the medium term.

Data released on Friday showed that inflation eased in several German states in February, while preliminary figures showed consumer prices in France rising more than expected, underscoring that the disinflation trend could be uneven across the bloc.

"This does not, however, signal a marked resurgence in inflationary pressures," said ING's senior economist Charlotte de Montpellier.

"France should therefore continue to be among the countries with the lowest inflation rates in the euro area."

The yield on France's 10-year OAT government bond was 3 bps lower at 3.22%, marking the sixth consecutive day of declines and hovering at its lowest since June. (FR10YT=RR). French bonds outperformed Bunds, with yields falling 20 bps in February.

The gap between French and German yields (DE10FR10=RR) was 54 bps on Friday, the lowest since June 10. It has shrunk in recent weeks after climbing to 71.6 bps in January.

Separately, the ECB's monthly survey showed euro zone consumers trimmed their inflation expectations last month.

The central bank is expected to hold rates at least through the end of the year, according to a Reuters poll of economists earlier this month.

The German two-year yield (DE2YT=RR), which is more sensitive to interest-rate expectations, was 4 bps lower at 2.01%.

Purchase of Own Securities

On 27 February 2026, the Company announces the purchase of 121,000 Ordinary Shares at a price of 205.50p. The shares purchased will be held in Treasury.

data.title: REG - B&M European - Migration Completion
data.description:
RNS Number : 7884U B&M European Value Retail S.A. 27 February 2026  

NOT FOR RELEASE, PUBLICATION OR DISTRIBUTION, IN WHOLE OR IN PART, DIRECTLY OR INDIRECTLY, IN OR INTO OR FROM ANY JURISDICTION WHERE TO DO SO WOULD CONSTITUTE A VIOLATION OF THE RELEVANT LAWS OR REGULATIONS OF SUCH JURISDICTION

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

27 February 2026

Completion of Migration

Further to the announcement on 25 February 2026 in relation to the approval and publication of its prospectus (the "Prospectus"), the Company is pleased to announce that all of the conditions to completion of the Migration have now been satisfied, and the Migration has become effective.

As a result of the Migration having been completed, the Company is now registered in Jersey as B&M European Value Retail plc under company number 164498. The new registered address for B&M Jersey is 26 New Street, St Helier, Jersey JE2 3RA. Notwithstanding that it is now registered as a public limited company under the laws of Jersey, the Company has continuity of legal personality pursuant to the Migration.

An application has been made to the Financial Conduct Authority ("FCA") for the admission of 1,005,038,256 ordinary shares of £0.10 each in the capital of B&M Jersey (the "B&M Jersey Shares") to the Equity Shares (Commercial Companies) Category of the FCA and to trading on the main market for listed security of London Stock Exchange plc (the "Admission"). It is expected that Admission will occur at 8:00 a.m. on 2 March 2026.

B&M Jersey Shares held in uncertificated form will be credited to the relevant CREST accounts upon admission which will occur at 8:00 a.m. on 2 March 2026. A small number of shareholders with suspended voting rights will receive a letter from B&M Jersey outlining the information such shareholders will be required to provide in order to receive their share certificates. Upon receipt of the requested information, the share certificates in respect of B&M Jersey Shares held in certificated form will be despatched to such shareholders. For further information please refer to the FAQ document here.

The new ISIN for B&M Jersey is JE00BVSYJW51. The ticker for B&M Jersey is unchanged and will therefore remain as BME.

Capitalised terms used but not defined herein have the meanings given to them in the Prospectus published by the Company on 25 February 2026.

Merrill Lynch International ("BofA Securities") is acting as sponsor under the UK Listing Rules in relation to Admission.

Enquiries

B&M European Value Retail plc

Alexander Simpson (Group General Counsel)

+44 (0) 151 728 5400 Ext. 6363

Andrew Orchard (Head of Investor Relations)

Investor.relations@bandmretail.com

Important Notice

The release, publication or distribution of this announcement in jurisdictions other than the United Kingdom may be restricted by law and therefore any persons who are subject to the laws of any jurisdiction other than the United Kingdom should inform themselves about, and observe, any applicable requirements. The information disclosed in this announcement may not be the same as that which would have been disclosed if this announcement had been prepared in accordance with the laws and regulations of any jurisdiction outside of the United Kingdom.

This announcement is not intended to, and does not constitute, or form part of, an offer to sell or an invitation to purchase or subscribe for any securities or a solicitation of any vote or approval in any jurisdiction. This announcement does not constitute a prospectus or a prospectus equivalent document.

Disclaimer

BofA Securities, which is authorised in the United Kingdom by the Prudential Regulation Authority ("PRA") and regulated in the United Kingdom by the FCA and the PRA, is acting exclusively for the Company and no one else in connection with the Admission, and will not be responsible to anyone other the Company for providing the protections afforded to its clients or for providing advice in relation to the Admission or any transaction, matter, or arrangement referred to in this announcement.

This information is provided by RNS, the news service of the London Stock Exchange. RNS is approved by the Financial Conduct Authority to act as a Primary Information Provider in the United Kingdom. data.title: Brink's Stock Slides on Plans to Acquire NCR Atleos
data.description:
By Kelly Cloonan

Shares of Brink's Company declined on plans to acquire NCR Atleos for about $4 billion in cash and stock in a deal that combines two major players in the ATM business.

Brink's stock slid 17% to $113.20 on Friday. Shares have gained 23% in the past year

Truist Securities analysts said the share weakness is likely driven in part by Brink's increased leverage under the deal. Under the transaction, Brink's would assume about $2.6 billion of NCR Atleos' debt. The company also secured $4.5 billion in new bridge financing to pay for part of the cash portion of the deal.

Investors may also have concerns that the deal could pose a distraction given the company expects it will take about a year to close, the analysts said.

Still, the analysts said they are optimistic the deal should benefit Brink's, forecasting combined revenue of $11.8 billion in 2029, up from Brink's revenue of $5.26 billion in 2025.

"We embrace the combination," the analysts said. "The ATM Outsourcing market is thriving as banks focus on core internal ops."

Both Brink's and NCR Atleos operate a vast number of ATMs around the globe. Brink's is also known for securely transporting cash, as well as stocking it into ATMs through their ubiquitous Brink's trucks.

Brinks said the deal would boost its scale and geographic footprint, adding 78,000 owned-and-operated ATMs to its own network. Brinks fully operates 135,000 ATMs. Both companies also service a much broader footprint of cash-dispensing machines.

The deal includes 13.3 million shares of Brink's common stock and $2.2 billion in cash, plus the assumption of about $2.6 billion of NCR Atleos' debt.

Under the deal, Brink's will acquire each outstanding share of NCR Atleos for $30 in cash and about 0.16 share of Brink's common stock. Upon closing, Brink's shareholders would own about 78% and NCR Atleos shareholders would own about 22% of the outstanding shares of Brink's common stock, the companies said.

The cash portion of the purchase price will be financed with cash as well as new debt raised.

The transaction has been approved by the boards of both companies. It is expected to close in the first quarter of 2027.

Write to Kelly Cloonan at kelly.cloonan@wsj.com

data.title: Braemar Hotels & Resorts: Resort-driven growth and asset sales offset renovation impacts as the company pursues a sale
data.description:
Q4 and full-year 2025 saw modest revenue and EBITDA growth, led by strong resort performance and strategic asset sales. Renovations and weather disruptions impacted results, but the portfolio remains resilient as the company explores a potential sale and continues deleveraging.

Based on Braemar Hotels & Resorts Q4 2025 Audio Transcript — Feb. 27 2026
